item.title: Meeting Participants and Invitations
item.description: Participants: Mr. Rye, Mr. Archer (present in the call), Anthony (invited), Micah, Eric, Scott, Katrina, Noah, Paul, Sarah, Emily Cronin, Jessica, Anna, and Lance (all mentioned in the discussion).

item.title: Meeting Participants and Invitations
item.description: Decision to invite Anthony to the call and include him in regular interactions, including a standing call, to align on cash projections and future business forecasting.

item.title: Meeting Participants and Invitations
item.description: Plan to schedule daily stand-up calls to ensure the team stays on the same page, receives necessary support, and identifies if anything is going off track.

item.title: Cash Flow and Forecasting
item.description: Cash flow visibility: Daily updates showed an increase from $31K to $39K, which was not considered "very good"; a drop in collections was attributed to a holiday.

item.title: Cash Flow and Forecasting
item.description: Cash projections discussed:

item.title: Cash Flow and Forecasting
item.description: Micahâ€™s machine learning model predicts insurance cash flows for existing business with historical accuracy within 5% of actual collections. This model is granular, analyzing average DSO by payer and prefix.

item.title: Cash Flow and Forecasting
item.description: Ryeâ€™s approach focuses on private history and includes private pay, which is considered a sensible approach for those averages.

item.title: Cash Flow and Forecasting
item.description: Agreement to combine Micahâ€™s insurance forecast (for existing business) with Ryeâ€™s private pay projections, and Anthony will collaborate with Micah to forecast future business cash flow.

item.title: Cash Flow and Forecasting
item.description: The rolling average method is considered the smartest approach for cash flow projections.

item.title: Cash Flow and Forecasting
item.description: The RefRec template is now being used 100% of the time in Sage, enabling more accurate RefRec forecasts instead of relying solely on rolling averages.

item.title: P&L and General Ledger (GL) Taxonomy
item.description: Noted confusion in the P&L due to summing many numbers and grouped GL buckets, requiring review.

item.title: P&L and General Ledger (GL) Taxonomy
item.description: A taxonomy has been created to:

item.title: P&L and General Ledger (GL) Taxonomy
item.description: Classify client accounts by priority (e.g., client safety, regulatory) to guide payment prioritization.

item.title: P&L and General Ledger (GL) Taxonomy
item.description: Guide payment prioritization across departments, acknowledging the complexity of balancing bills and departmental needs without ignoring any.

item.title: P&L and General Ledger (GL) Taxonomy
item.description: GL reconciliation discussed:

item.title: P&L and General Ledger (GL) Taxonomy
item.description: Separate review of accounts is needed to verify that items marked for cancellation (e.g., Sims' cancellations) were actually canceled.

item.title: P&L and General Ledger (GL) Taxonomy
item.description: An aggregated general ledger report, including scores and a prioritized list for pending bills and expenses, will be provided to check if items have been removed.

item.title: Closing Deadlines and Payment Scheduling
item.description: Target dates for closing accounts: A business day deadline (around the 10th or 15th) was discussed, with final closure agreed upon with Eric by the 20th. The team is in a good position to beat the 20th.

item.title: Closing Deadlines and Payment Scheduling
item.description: Emphasis on rapid closure ("faster is better") to proactively address potential cash shortfalls.

item.title: Closing Deadlines and Payment Scheduling
item.description: Need for a method-based Accounts Payable (AP) process to prevent overpayment (e.g., avoiding a single $300K vendor payment). The goal is to establish a governing document for AP by the next quarter.

item.title: System Integrations and Data Management
item.description: Effort to transcribe recent messages and current discussions for record-keeping and future reference.

item.title: System Integrations and Data Management
item.description: SAGE and LBMC discussed:

item.title: System Integrations and Data Management
item.description: A project plan drafted by Arthur, outlining tasks, responsibilities, and constraints, is scheduled for discussion tomorrow.

item.title: System Integrations and Data Management
item.description: NetSuite layered books, allocation journals, and accrual journals are under review to correct discrepancies caused by Eric's import template, which only pulled accruals and missed corporate allocations.

item.title: System Integrations and Data Management
item.description: NetSuite will serve as the source of truth for 2024 financial records, a time-intensive process estimated at four hours per site for December data alone (12 months x 9 locations).

item.title: System Integrations and Data Management
item.description: Future plans include setting up reconciliation and matching rules in Sage, potentially integrating AI for faster processing, though the team currently lacks knowledge on how to use these features, and Eric never utilized them.

item.title: Accruals, Revenue Recognition, and Forecast Adjustments
item.description: Debate on using actual cash collections versus standard accruals:

item.title: Accruals, Revenue Recognition, and Forecast Adjustments
item.description: Noah prefers accrual based on average in-network rates, but this method has led to significant discrepancies (never within 30%) compared to actual cash collections, making board meetings feel like a "magic show."

item.title: Accruals, Revenue Recognition, and Forecast Adjustments
item.description: The variety in insurance payments (e.g., United Healthcare) complicates accrual accuracy.

item.title: Accruals, Revenue Recognition, and Forecast Adjustments
item.description: Discussion of "comic book" P&L versions (a metaphor for investor-facing vs. internal P&Ls) and the potential for high/mid/low scenarios to manage investor perceptions, while being cautious about "defrauding investors," especially with a "tough" CPA on the board.

item.title: Accruals, Revenue Recognition, and Forecast Adjustments
item.description: Need to track contractual adjustments and bad debt, with a suggestion to initially write off bad debt and add it back if collected, similar to a historical "quarterly adjustment bucket."

item.title: Accruals, Revenue Recognition, and Forecast Adjustments
item.description: Suggestion to have Anthony join calls with Eric to understand year-to-date performance and Eric's past forecasting methods, particularly noting the "sloppiness" of his Excel work and its translation into the accounting system.

item.title: Staffing and Resource Allocation
item.description: The finance function is under-resourced, likened to having "too many chiefs and not enough Indians."

item.title: Staffing and Resource Allocation
item.description: Proposal to add two or three additional staff ("Scots" or similar) to support cash flow reconciliation and revenue tracking.

item.title: Staffing and Resource Allocation
item.description: Discussion on the necessity of training and onboarding new team members, potentially with Scott's oversight, to ensure the finance function is well-staffed and avoids future suffering.

item.title: Staffing and Resource Allocation
item.description: Plan to leverage Scottâ€™s expertise for cash reconciliation, then transition him to revenue and bad debt management.

item.description: Tax documentation issues (W-9s and W-2s):

item.title: Human Resources and Vendor/Employee Documentation
item.description: Several employees reported discrepancies, such as having the wrong W-2, only one W-2, or multiple W-2s (e.g., Katrina received two W-2s and a corrected W-2).

item.title: Human Resources and Vendor/Employee Documentation
item.description: Resolution: The issue stemmed from Lance's failure to close out the previous system before PayCore. PayCore issued W-2s for the first quarter, which were superseded by corrected W-2s, and to the company's knowledge, all employees should now have the correct forms.

item.title: Human Resources and Vendor/Employee Documentation
item.description: HR concerns about external representation:

item.title: Human Resources and Vendor/Employee Documentation
item.description: Concerns regarding Paulâ€™s role in representing the company, as he is perceived as more effort than value, and the speaker is uncomfortable with him representing the company in the community, leading to a potential separation.

item.title: Human Resources and Vendor/Employee Documentation
item.description: Plan to discuss sensitive HR matters with Sarah, copying Emily Cronin, who serves as the HR consultant.

item.title: Additional Financial and Operational Considerations
item.description: Detailed review of revenue buckets: The four main buckets are private pay, insurance payments, paid to subscriber (PTS), and inside sales/extensions. Insurance and private pay are the largest.

item.title: Additional Financial and Operational Considerations
item.description: Extensions and inside sales revenues are tracked using a client taxonomy: P1 (private pay, no discount), P2 (private pay, some discount), I-1 (good insurance rate/deductibles paid), I-2 (barely scraping by), and scholarship. This taxonomy will eventually help predict revenue based on census data, but it will take about six months to flesh out. PTS can be volatile.

item.title: Additional Financial and Operational Considerations
item.description: Expense management: Accurate future expense projections are crucial for APN, which is currently distressed. The goal is to reduce recurring expenses to below $4 million (currently $4.2 million), acknowledging that expenses increase with growth.

item.title: Additional Financial and Operational Considerations
item.description: Coordination with external parties: Ongoing discussions with LBMC involve receiving "homework" and learning how to perform tasks offline.

item.title: Additional Financial and Operational Considerations
item.description: Emphasis on using free resources and making cost-conscious operational decisions, exemplified by Jessica's budget-minded approach. The company aims to reach $3.5-$3.6 million in cash to break even, having reached $3.4 million last month.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: **SharePoint System Growth and Issues**

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: The SharePoint environment has expanded rapidly and gone "rogue," resulting in a proliferation of sites and a significant lack of centralized control.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: Creation of new team and communication sites has been prohibited to curb uncontrolled growth, but some users still retain this ability, posing ongoing risk.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: Issues include confusion over document locations, inconsistent communication, and increased risk exposure due to the difficulty in knowing where information and documents reside.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: Establishing better structure for posting policies is a key objective to ensure everyone knows where to find them, addressing current disorganization where the "left hand is not talking to the right hand."

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: **Permission and External Sharing Risks**

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: Permissions are overly permissive and have "crept up," with widespread use of sharing links offering "anyone with a link" edit or read access.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: External sharing has grown exponentially since 2023; while some is justified, much poses significant HIPAA and security risks, requiring better control.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: Compared to Vail Health, a local hospital that has prohibited all external sharing due to HIPAA complaints and investigations, APNâ€™s more distributed and remote nature requires a tailored approach to external sharing.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: The current system poses HIPAA risks and challenges with external sharing and permission levels.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: **Navigation and Adoption Problems**

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: SharePoint site adoption is low; most users prefer team sites or OneDrive due to familiarity and the perceived ease of use, despite efforts to encourage specific SharePoint site usage.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: Absence of a centralized intranet or home site makes navigation and document retrieval difficult, contributing to a lack of organization and a "huge challenge" for navigation.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: Example: A financial document was created outside its secure finance folder, leading to increased visibility and reduced security, highlighting the need for a more organized audit process.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: The current environment lacks a true intranet, making it difficult for users to navigate directly to internal SharePoint sites.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: **Departmental and Process Complexity**

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: The organization comprises over 24 simplified departments (e.g., acquisition, business development, contact center, ancillary) with unique needs, plus cross-functional processes requiring shared access and communication (e.g., clinical services in client lifecycle management).

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: The current folder-based hierarchy, where one team site contains individual folder structures, is ambiguous and confusing, leading to frequent questions in the ticket system. Other organizations use a cleaner site-per-department model.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: **Structural Overhaul**

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Transition to a site-per-department and site-per-process model, giving each department its own SharePoint site, with the vision that "everything you could ever need is going to be on there, it's indexed."

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Universal access to policies and procedures via links on each site, ensuring common resources are readily available.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Clear separation of public and private files, with permissions based on role (frontline workers, middle management, senior management) within each department.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: The overall structure needs to be driven by business needs, defining deliverables, constraints, milestones, and stakeholder engagement.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: **Centralized Home Site**

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Establish a SharePoint home site (intranet) as the single entry point for all staff, providing a psychologically safe and high-functioning environment.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: The home site will feature announcements, general HR documents, links to department/process sites, and serve as a template for sub-sites, making it easier to update and maintain data consistency.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: This will improve onboarding, communication, and reduce confusion by providing a clear starting point for all information.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: A home site would also provide a template for file structure and hierarchy for individual team sites.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: **Security and Permissions**

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Use security groups to control access and external sharing based on organizational roles, allowing specific capabilities for certain groups while restricting others.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Limit external sharing to only those who require it (e.g., investor relations needing to communicate with 200 investors); restrict for clinical staff to comply with HIPAA, as their client-related sharing should occur via secure email or Kifu.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Conduct regular audits and utilize reports to monitor site activity, data volume, and relevance, including utilization stats and last use dates to identify unused sites.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Implement a "member-visitor scale" for managing download and edit access per site based on department and role.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: **Change Management and Adoption**

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Emphasize cultural adoption and clear communication about the reasons for change, recognizing that this is a significant shift.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Recommend a leadership statement (video or document) to transparently explain the rationale and benefits, fostering buy-in and outlining the end goal and pathway.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Conduct training at least annually on Teams, SharePoint, OneDrive, email, and Zoom, as current ticket system requests indicate a tremendous need for training.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: A "behavior first framework" will be used to guide and direct the transition.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: **Phased Implementation**

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Begin with a small, targeted pilot (e.g., the home site) to demonstrate value and refine the approach, allowing for scaling with intent.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Use data (utilization stats, last access dates, sheer amount of data) to prioritize which sites/folders to migrate or clean up, identifying where to start.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Roll out the new structure gradually, incorporating ongoing feedback and adjustments, with a focus on design and planning before implementation.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: The project is expected to bring long-term ROI, making it a worthwhile endeavor to chip away at.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: **Audit and Inventory**

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: Plan to distribute an Excel spreadsheet inventory of all current SharePoint sites, groups, and folders for review and cleanup, shared via SharePoint and APN email for collaboration.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: Include utilization reports showing activity levels, data volumes, and member counts per site/group to identify usage patterns and potential "rogue" groups.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: **Examples of Issues**

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: Financial documents created outside the finance folder, leading to security concerns and highlighting the need for better organization.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: Frequent support tickets regarding document locations and access, indicating widespread confusion.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: Deletion of five outdated COVID-related sites as part of initial cleanup efforts, demonstrating the need for ongoing maintenance.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: Issues with users incorrectly setting access permissions, leading to files being corrupted or inaccessible.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: The challenge of consolidating or migrating information from potentially 500 existing email groups/SharePoint sites.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: **External Sharing**

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: Currently enabled but under review; some departments (e.g., investor relations) require it for operational needs, while others (e.g., clinical staff) do not and should be restricted for HIPAA compliance.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: The current restriction on external sharing was temporarily lifted but can be easily re-imposed or managed by groups.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: **Consulting and Resources**

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: Reference to a previous consulting engagement with Able Consulting in 2023 for SharePoint/intranet design, indicating prior exploration of solutions.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: Internal resource constraints acknowledged; there is a need to balance project work with ongoing operations and avoid detracting from internal resources that generate revenue.

item.title: # Conclusions
item.description: The current SharePoint environment is fragmented, insecure, difficult to navigate, and has grown "rogue" without sufficient control.

item.title: # Conclusions
item.description: There is consensus on the need for a more structured, department-based and process-based site architecture anchored by a central home site (intranet).

item.title: # Conclusions
item.description: Security, compliance (especially HIPAA), user adoption, and clear communication are primary concerns that must be addressed.

item.title: # Conclusions
item.description: A phased, data-driven approach is preferred, starting with a pilot (like the home site) and scaling up, with a focus on design and planning.

item.title: # Conclusions
item.description: Ongoing training, clear communication, leadership support, and a "behavior first framework" are critical for the project's success and cultural adoption.

item.title: # Conclusions
item.description: The project is considered very important for organizational efficiency, protection of staff and clients, and data security.

item.title: # Communication and Discharge Process

item.title: Project Overview
item.description: Identification of targeted provider registry data, including machine-readable files and provider details with MPI (National Provider Identifier) and taxonomy codes.

item.title: Project Overview
item.description: Emphasis on leveraging publicly available data, specifically the national provider database, to support an $80 million lawsuit involving Blue Cross Blue Shield. This data is considered crucial for legal standing, as Blue Cross and similar companies are mandated by the Data Transparency Act to publish accurate information.

item.title: Project Overview
item.description: Focus on precise provider mapping, filtering by specific taxonomy codes to isolate relevant facilities, primarily substance use disorder facilities.

item.title: Data and Technical Requirements
item.description: Extraction of provider registry data, confirmed to be a completely free dataset that covers the entire inspection of providers.

item.title: Data and Technical Requirements
item.description: Data filtering based on client-supplied taxonomy codes is essential to narrow the list, specifically excluding multi-specialty clinics and focusing on two primary taxonomy codes, including one for substance use disorder facilities and another for primary mental health.

item.title: Data and Technical Requirements
item.description: Use of MPI numbers as unique lookup keys after initial filtering to facilitate further data retrieval and verification.

item.title: Data and Technical Requirements
item.description: Significant challenges with raw datasets include their large file sizes and inherent machine memory limitations, which have previously caused scraping failures.

item.title: Data and Technical Requirements
item.description: A notable failed attempt involved using a Python script, generated by ChatGPT, to extract files from Alabama; this script ran for 90 minutes before ultimately failing due to memory constraints.

item.title: Data and Technical Requirements
item.description: Consideration of anti-scraping measures implemented on provider websites, which may necessitate advanced scraping techniques such as grid-based scraping and subsequent rigorous dataset cleaning.

item.title: Work Process and Technical Approach
item.description: Proposal to utilize an existing Maptiv account for visualizing the provider registry data, leveraging its pre-built base map for efficiency and ease of use.

item.title: Work Process and Technical Approach
item.description: Integration of multiple data sources, including insights from a shared GitHub project for a provider database, although this specific project has limitations in mapping due to latitude and longitude restrictions.

item.title: Work Process and Technical Approach
item.description: A key plan is to create a heat map visualization, segmented into three distinct colors by taxonomy, to facilitate easier identification of in-network versus out-of-network providers and assess network adequacy.

item.title: Work Process and Technical Approach
item.description: The scraping strategy will prioritize cleaning the main MPPI dataset first, getting it visualized, and then proceeding with the scraper to collect additional, more granular data points.

item.title: Work Process and Technical Approach
item.description: Scraper performance and project feasibility will be evaluated by testing the process on specific states, such as Colorado, to establish baseline metrics and inform the overall timeline.

item.title: Work Process and Technical Approach
item.description: Manual verification steps, such as having administrators call facilities in states like Nebraska, will be employed if automated scraping proves insufficient or for rural areas.

item.title: Work Process and Technical Approach
item.description: Comprehensive documentation is required for all scraper work, including storing raw files in a dedicated folder and uploading all findings to a private GitHub repository to ensure access and traceability.

item.title: Payment Structure and Agreement Details
item.description: The project is proposed to operate on an hourly basis, with an initial block cap set at 50 hours.

item.title: Payment Structure and Agreement Details
item.description: The estimated rate for this block is $3,000, with an understanding that flexibility will be applied if unforeseen technical limitations (such as bandwidth or processing constraints) arise, ensuring payment up to the hours logged if the project needs to stop.

item.title: Payment Structure and Agreement Details
item.description: Consideration will be given to drafting a formal statement of work or agreement to structure the project professionally, especially for potential future collaborations.

item.title: Payment Structure and Agreement Details
item.description: Assurance of payment process is provided, with the client controlling the purse strings and emphasizing the importance of careful logging of hours.

item.title: Additional Considerations
item.description: Discussion included the potential use of an API for Blue Cross Blue Shield data extraction if available, or otherwise relying on public provider registry data mandated by Data Transparency Acts.

item.title: Additional Considerations
item.description: A significant concern regarding the MPPI dataset's legal validity was raised, as it primarily provides a list of providers but does not confirm whether they are actively offering services in-network, necessitating a second phase of scraping to validate service provision.

item.title: Additional Considerations
item.description: The possibility to shift focus to alternative datasets, such as state licensure data, was discussed as a contingency if Blue Cross-related scraping becomes too complex or fails to yield accurate network adequacy data. For example, the lack of subacute mental health licenses in states like Texas could form a basis for a legal case, as patients may have no in-state options for certain types of care.

item.title: Additional Considerations
item.description: The use of additional taxonomy filters is crucial to exclude non-relevant provider data, such as primary care or multi-specialty clinics, ensuring the focus remains on specific behavioral health services.

item.title: Additional Considerations
item.description: Future collaborative opportunities were discussed, including potential full-scale consulting projects and team-building to establish a "McKinsey and Company of Behavioral Health," depending on the successful outcome and insights from this initial investigation.

item.description: Filing must be completed promptly to present the case before a judge.

item.title: Claims Analysis and Filing Strategy
item.description: If Colorado alone provides sufficient grounds, the process may proceed without expanding to other states.

item.title: Data Visualization Requirements
item.description: Visualizations (maps) are intended for a judge as part of an injunctive hearing, focusing on injunctive relief due to financial distress caused by non-payment.

item.title: Data Visualization Requirements
item.description: Visualizations should be professional and clear, suitable for a legal audience.

item.title: Data Visualization Requirements
item.description: Standard heat maps or dot maps are acceptable; mimicking official forestry or state map styles is recommended for normalization to the judge.

item.title: Data Visualization Requirements
item.description: Multiple visualization options can be provided, as their technical implementation is straightforward.

item.title: Data Visualization Requirements
item.description: Source documentation must accompany all visualizations.

item.title: Balance Sheet Reconciliation and System Integration

item.title: Balance Sheet Reconciliation and System Integration
item.description: Scott is verifying subledgers, such as cash tied to bank accounts, and ensuring key accounts (revenues, AR reserves, AP) reconcile, impacting the P&L.

item.title: Deferred Revenue and Allocation Process
item.description: Deferred revenue refers to cash received before it is earned (unearned revenue), distinct from accruals for earned revenue.

item.title: Deferred Revenue and Allocation Process
item.description: NetSuite holds the deferred revenue figure, which must reconcile with Sage using a subledger or schedule to identify the source/customer.

item.title: Deferred Revenue and Allocation Process
item.description: Allocation training is needed, as cash allocation is currently manual due to staff not knowing how to process this in Sage.

item.title: Cash Flow Reporting and Forecasting
item.description: A weekly cash flow report will be generated using the RISE file as the source of truth, but improvements are needed in communication (assumptions, top spend details) and visual tools like a 13-week projection graph.

item.title: Cash Flow Reporting and Forecasting
item.description: Forecasts are compared by reviewing forecasted versus actual collections (targeting 94â€“95% accuracy) and analyzing forecasted volumes.

item.title: Cash Flow Reporting and Forecasting
item.description: Call volume is the leading indicator, with plans to use six weeks of historical data (doubled for a 13-week forecast).

item.title: Cash Flow Reporting and Forecasting
item.description: Discussions include integrating Salesforce data (via an â€œexecutive dataâ€ file) and exploring machine learning models that weigh variables like web page views and admission conversion rates to refine forecasts.

item.description: Historical month-end close challenges stemmed from the SAGE transition and prior checklist inefficiencies.

item.description: A detailed checklist (used before SAGE reconciliation issues) outlines items to be completed by specific business days.

item.title: Month-End Close Process Improvements
item.description: A structured close process, including CFO/controller review before final submission to management, is needed for accountability and timely reporting.

item.title: Month-End Close Process Improvements
item.description: Scott may shift from cash management to focus on SAGE implementation support and controlling tasks D1â€“D6.

item.title: Accounts Payable and Vendor Expense Controls
item.description: Discussion centered on disorganized expense tagging and allocation in the general ledger.

item.title: Accounts Payable and Vendor Expense Controls
item.description: Power Query is used to categorize transactions by department, criticality, and necessity, ranking expenses (e.g., food cost per patient day, auto floor expenses) and flagging items for cancellation or review.

item.title: Accounts Payable and Vendor Expense Controls
item.description: Tags must be aligned across systems (clinical, administrative, nursing costs) to ensure accurate departmental allocations.

item.title: Accounts Payable and Vendor Expense Controls
item.description: Analysis of recurring spending via Bill.com and Brex was emphasized. Brex is recommended for real-time expense control, with API integration planned.

item.title: Accounts Payable and Vendor Expense Controls
item.description: Future reporting may automatically separate fixed and variable expenses, especially those tied to patient days, admissions, or discharges.

item.title: Integrating Business Intelligence (BI) and Real-Time Reporting

item.description: The new system will filter data by facility and adjust for rank formulas on expense criticality, supporting strategic decisions.

item.title: Integrating Business Intelligence (BI) and Real-Time Reporting
item.description: Planned BI enhancements include granular reports by expense category (fixed, variable, semi-fixed) and tracking KPIs (e.g., per patient day revenue, food cost optimization) operationally.

item.description: Speaker 1's ongoing duties include teaching, graduation programming, and general alumni engagement at "the lodge."

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: Speaker 1, currently "Director of Alumni Programs," is considering a title change to "Senior Director" or "Senior Director of Programming," noting that a long title isn't necessary for feeling valued.

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: Speaker 1 proposes creating content (e.g., for Instagram or YouTube) to maintain alumni connections, viewing it as a "value add" to their job.

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: The upfront cost would be minimal, requiring only a small handheld camera, as Speaker 1 is already present at "the lodge" and can video and edit.

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: Content ideas include "Top Tip from Tammy" or quick vignettes from therapists like "What's a good DBT skill for Wednesday?"

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: The goal is to keep alumni connected to therapists, the organization, and educational resources, allowing them to see familiar faces and be reminded of skills and motivation, without needing a huge team.

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: There is no current alumni engagement app, despite previous discussions with Jeremy about integrating alumni into one.

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: Speaker 1 has explored white-labeled app solutions, which are liked but expensive (e.g., $2,400/month).

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: The organization currently lacks a dedicated person for tasks like sending e-blasts, making content creation a low-overhead way to add value, create connection and community, and establish thought leadership without adding staff or detracting from core competencies.

item.description: Topics for discussion include pre-, peri-, and post-treatment goals, and compensation.

item.title: # Strategic Planning and Organizational Goals
item.description: Speaker 2 aspires for the organization to be recognized as the best treatment center in Colorado, though acknowledges not everyone would give a "resounding yes." Speaker 1, however, believes they are the best treatment center in Colorado, period.

item.description: Strengths identified include strong residential and PHP programs.

item.title: # Strategic Planning and Organizational Goals

item.title: # Strategic Planning and Organizational Goals
item.description: There is an ongoing need for improvement to solidify the organization's position as the best.

item.title: Definitions and Classifications
item.description: **"Unable to disclose"**: The insurance company explicitly refused to provide the information.

item.title: Definitions and Classifications
item.description: **"Unknown"**: No contact could be made with the insurance company to obtain the information. It was also suggested and agreed upon to reclassify this status as â€œnot yet identifiedâ€ for improved clarity.

item.title: Definitions and Classifications
item.description: **"Paid to subscriber"**: Indicates that the claim was paid to the client, confirmed once the Explanation of Benefits (EOB) is received.

item.title: Spreadsheet and Data Management
item.description: The spreadsheet contains a complex dataset with about 22,000 lines.

item.title: Spreadsheet and Data Management
item.description: The creation of this spreadsheet was noted as one of the most challenging tasks undertaken at APN, providing significant learning opportunities, including identifying inefficiencies.

item.title: Spreadsheet and Data Management
item.description: Detailed explanations for claim statuses are included alongside the data.

item.title: Spreadsheet and Data Management
item.description: The file uses Power Query and requires an online component, but is currently managed offline.

item.title: Network Adequacy Map and Data Mapping Process
item.description: NOAA requested a network adequacy map, which involves managing large datasets (about 10GB per state).

item.title: Network Adequacy Map and Data Mapping Process
item.description: The process includes pulling data from the National Provider Registry, cross-referencing taxonomy codes, and mapping these to Blue Cross MPI numbers.

item.title: Network Adequacy Map and Data Mapping Process
item.description: A former employee (with a background in crypto and computing) raised concerns about the legal defensibility of this mapping method.

item.title: Network Adequacy Map and Data Mapping Process
item.description: Extensive research has been conducted to ensure the defensibility of the approach, and the mapping process itself is estimated to require about 50 hours of work.

item.description: The developer is responsible for processing the network adequacy map on a state-by-state basis.

item.description: There is a verbal agreement for an additional $6,000 cost, verified by Katrina.

item.title: Project Development and Financial Considerations
item.description: Flexibility has been granted on deadlines to accommodate the complexity and ensure quality.
